page.title: 18GEOLOGY OF N. BREDON HILL
page.content: The geological succession at Bredon Hill is revealed by topographic and lithological observation.Heavy soils derived from superficial deposition of the Avon river terraces and underlying lower lias clay are seen at Chapel Farm.At the junction of lower with middle lias are springs and boggy ground (underlying tufa or chalk).At the surface,middle lias is rich,brown loam.Castle Hill is a middle lias bench and scarp face with ferruginous, calcareous sandstone.Marlstone rock beds are an intermediate "midslope" scarp feature on the 160m contour.The upper lias,earthflow/mudflow of the landslipped upper slopes is composed of shales and mudstones.The oolitic cap is the escarpment (963404)- calcareous loams and shell limestones.
